thread.title: Stormageddon #2: Brace yourselves for another lashing
thread.title_full: Stormageddon #2: Brace yourselves for another lashing

title: Stormageddon #2: Brace yourselves for another lashing
text:
TWO people have been struck by lightning as furious rail, hail and thunder swept through Sydney’s southern and central regions for the second time in eight days. 
Lightning also struck a Qantas plane as it was preparing to land at Sydney airport this afternoon. 
Storm chaser Daniel Shaw posted dramatic footage of the incident on social media describing it a “close call”. Another terrifying image of the @qantas lightning close call in Sydney Australia. pic.twitter.com/0zTNEuEHdx — Daniel Shaw (@DanielShawAU) October 20, 2015 VIDEO: Close call for @Qantas aircraft after lightning strikes nearby during landing in Sydney Australia. https://t.co/U87ULMdBJZ — Daniel Shaw (@DanielShawAU) October 20, 2015 
The first person who was struck by lightning, a woman, remains in a stable condition, was hit at about 5pm in St Marys. 
Emergency services were called to Waratah Street after reports of a person being struck by lightning. 
She was treated by paramedics and taken to Nepean Hospital in a stable condition. 
The second woman, a female in her mid-20s, was struck while she was in Newtown’s Camperdown Memorial Park on Lennox Street. 
Paramedics responded to reports of a woman being struck by lightning just before 6pm. 
“She’s in a stable condition at the moment,” intensive care paramedic inspector Rob Murray said. 
“We are certainly treating her for a lightning strike,” Mr Murray said. 
“We are taking all the precautions,” he said. 
An ambulance spokeswoman said the woman was being taken to Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in a “serious but stable condition”. 
The extent of the injuries caused to both women are not yet known. 
Localised storms were rolling through districts from as far west as the Blue Mountains, into Liverpool, Campbelltown and were heading for the Sutherland Shire and coastal areas during the midafternoon. 
Heavy rain swamped the CBD and inner-city regions by 6pm and soon left, but a second wave was looming for later in the evening. 
Ausgrid tweeted alerts of damaged power systems, to say emergency crews were working to get power back to about 1600 homes and businesses in parts of Ashfield and Croydon. 
News_Image_File: Paramedics rush a woman in RPA Hospital after she was struck by lightning at Camperdown Memorial Park in Newtown. Picture: Richard Dobson News_Image_File: Bronte's Harry McRitchie jumps off a cliff at Nielsen Point. Picture: Dylan Robinson News_Image_File: The storm rolls over Erskineville Oval. Picture: Carly Earl News_Image_File: Lightning strikes over Bondi. Picture: Mark Evans Life support customers should consider acting on backup plans as storm cuts power to 10,000 homes around Arncliffe & 500 at Potts Hill
